text: Young Elk (1770–1795) was a chief of the Omaha tribe. The Diary of Hosea Stout describes him as the son of Big Elk, and says that he was involved in peace negotiations with a group of Mormons regarding return of six stolen horses. It is not clear whether Young Elk and Standing Elk, a son of Big Elk, are the same person.Robert A Trennert Jr, "The Mormons and the Office of Indian Affairs: The Conflict Over Winter Quarters, 1846-1848," Nebraska History 53 (1972): 381-400. == References == == External links == * *Standing Elk (Omaha), photographs by F. A. Rinehart, 1898, 1, 2, 3 Category:1770 births Category:1795 deaths Category:Native American leaders
title: Young Elk
